Statement 1: The statement "A ring homomorphism is one to one if and only if the kernel is {0}" is true. 

Explanation: A ring homomorphism \( \varphi: R \to S \) is said to be one-to-one (or injective) if for any two elements \( a, b \in R \), \( \varphi(a) = \varphi(b) \) implies \( a = b \). The kernel of the homomorphism \( \varphi \), denoted as \( \ker(\varphi) \), is the set of all elements in \( R \) that are mapped to the zero element in \( S \). 

According to the First Isomorphism Theorem for Rings, if \( \varphi: R \to S \) is a ring homomorphism with \( \varphi \) being one-to-one, then \( R/\ker(\varphi) \cong \text{Im}(\varphi) \), where \( \text{Im}(\varphi) \) denotes the image of \( \varphi \). If \( \ker(\varphi) = \{0\} \), then \( R/\{0\} \cong \text{Im}(\varphi) \), which means \( \text{Im}(\varphi) \) is isomorphic to the whole ring \( R \). This implies that \( \varphi \) is one-to-one.

question: Statement 1 | If H is a subgroup of G and a belongs to G then |aH| = |Ha|. Statement 2 | If H is a subgroup of G and a and b belong to G, then aH and Hb are identical or disjoint. (A) False, True (B) True, False
pred:
The statement |aH| = |Ha| in group theory is true, and this is a fundamental property of groups and subgroups. This property indicates that the left coset aH (formed by multiplying every element of H by a from the left) and the right coset Ha (formed by multiplying every element of a by H from the right) have the same cardinality (number of elements). This is a direct consequence of the definition of cosets and the properties of group actions.

Statement 2, however, is false. The assertion that if H is a subgroup of G and a and b belong to G, then aH and Hb are identical or disjoint, is incorrect. Cosets in general do not have to be identical or disjoint. They can be identical if a and b are in H (since Hb = aH in this case), but they can also be distinct even if a and b are in G. For example, consider G to be the group of integers under addition and H to be the subgroup of integers that are multiples of 2 (i.e., H = {0, 2, 4, ...}). Then, the cosets 2H and 3H are 2*{0, 2, 4, ...} = {0, 2, 4, ...} and 3*{0, 2, 4, ...} = {0, 3, 6, ...}, which are clearly distinct and not identical.

Therefore, the correct answer to the question is:

(B) True, False
